data.title: Famous People Who Died in 1961
data.meta_description: Famous deaths in 1961. Learn about 263 historical figures, notable people and celebrities who died in 1961 like Erwin Schrödinger, Ernest Hemingway and Ty Cobb.
data.text:
Deaths 1 - 200 of 263

Bob Catterall, South African cricket batsman (24 Tests, 3 x 100s, HS 120; Transvaal, Natal), dies at 60

Barry Fitzgerald, Irish actor (Academy Award, Going My Way), dies at 72

Erwin Schrödinger

Austrian physicist and Nobel Laureate (wave mechanics), dies at 73

Regina Ullmann, Swiss poet and writer, dies at 76

Clarice Baright, 1st woman admitted to American Bar Association, dies at 74

Lynwood Thomas "Schoolboy" Rowe, American baseball pitcher (Detroit Tigers), dies at 50

Emily Greene Balch, American sociologist, feminist and pacifist (Women's International League for Peace and Freedom - Nobel Peace Prize 1946), dies at 94

Dashiell Hammett, American detective writer (Thin Man, Maltese Falcon), dies at 66

Elena Gerhardt, German mezzo-soprano singer (b. 1883)

Blanche Ring, American singer ("In The Good Old Summer Time"), and stage and screen actress, dies at 89

Ernest Thesiger, English actor (Brass Monkey, Ghoul), dies at 81

Jan 14 Henry Geehl, English composer, dies at 79

Francesco Maria Saraceni, Italian composer, dies at 49

János Viski, Hungarian classical pianist, composer (Enigma), and teacher, dies at 54

Patrice Lumumba

Congolese politician and independence leader who was the 1st Prime Minister of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (1960), executed by the Katangan and Belgian government at 34

John Joseph Becker, American composer and conductor, dies a day before his 75th birthday

Alfred Carlton Gilbert

American inventor and businessman who invented the Erector Set, one of the most popular toys of all time, dies at 76

Willem van Eysinga, Dutch jurist and diplomat (Paris Peace Conference), dies at 82

Morris Nichols, English cricketer (41 wkts in 14 Tests for Eng 1930-39), dies at 60

Maud Wagner, first known American tattoo artist and circus performer, dies at about 83

Adolf Vogl, German composer, dies at 87

Anna May Wong [Wong Liu-tsong], Chinese-American actress, 1st Asian-American movie star (Shanghai Express; Gallery of Mme Lui-Tsang), and 1st Asian-American on US currency (American Women series quarter, 2022), dies of a heart attack at 56

Feb 3 William Morrison, 1st Viscount Dunrossil, British politician (Governor-General of Australia 1960-61), dies at 67

Piet[er] L. Kramer, Influential Dutch architect (Amsterdam School), dies at 79

Anthony Gustav de Rothschild, British philanthropist, dies at 73

Archibald T Davison, American musicologist and composer, dies at 77

William Duncan, Scottish actor (Hopalong Rides Again, Thunder Trail), dies at 81

Grigory Levenfish, Russian International chess grandmaster, dies at 70

Feb 9 Oscar Egg, Swiss track and road bicycle racer (3 x world hour record), dies at 70

Velma Middleton, American jazz vocalist (Louis Armstrong's big bands and small groups), dies from complications of a stroke at 43

Eduard R Verkade, Dutch actor and director (Pygmalion), dies at 82

Feb 11 Kate Carew [Mary Williams], American caricaturist, dies at 91

Wallis Clark, British-American stage and screen actor (Penny Serenade; Great Guy; Postal Inspector; Easy Money), dies at 78

Dudley Richards, American figure skater (U.S. Pairs champion, 1961), dies in a plane crash at 29

Feb 15 Jack Whiting, American actor and singer (Marge & Gower Champion Show), dies at 59

Feb 15 Laurence Owen, American figure skater (U.S. and North American champion), dies in a plane crash at 16

Maribel Vinson

American figure skater (9 time US National Champion) and coach, dies in a plane crash at 49

Feb 15 Maribel Yerxa Owen, American figure skater (U.S. Pairs champion, 1961), dies in a plane crash at 20

(Charles) "Dazzy" Vance, American Baseball HOF pitcher (7 x NL strike-out leader; World Series 1934 St Louis Cardinals; NL MVP & Triple Crown of Pitching,1924 Brooklyn Robins), dies at 69

Nita Naldi [Anita Donna Dooley], American stage and silent film actress (Blood & Sand; Dr. Jekyll & Mr. Hyde), dies of a heart attack at 66

Otto Huiswoud, Suriname-born political activist and editor-in-chief (Negro Worker), dies at 67

Feb 20 Percy Grainger, Australian-American concert pianist and composer (Hill Songs; Country Gardens), dies at 78

Blaise Cendrars [Frederic Sauser-Hall], Swiss poet and writer, dies at 73

Feb 21 Frederick McKinley Jones, American inventor (developments in refrigeration), dies of lung cancer at 67

George de Cuevas, Chilean-born ballet impresario and choreographer (Grand Ballet du Marquis de Cuevas), dies at 75 or 76

Feb 22 Nick LaRocca, American jazz coronetist and composer (Tiger Rag), dies at 71

Wilf Ferguson, West Indian cricket leg spinner (34 wickets for West Indies), dies at 43

Karl Albiker, German sculptor (Problem of the Plastic), dies at 83

Feb 26 Mohammed V, Sultan of Morrocco 1925-57), King of Morocco (1957-61), dies at 51

Platt Adams, American field athlete (Olympic gold standing high jump 1912), dies at 75

Joris Vriamont, Flemish writer and music publisher, dies at 64

Paul Wittgenstein, Austrian-born left-handed pianist, dies at 72

George Formby, British singer and comedian, dies at 56

Mar 6 Kjeld Abell, Danish playwright and director (Tivoli), dies at 59

Englebert van Anderlecht, Belgian abstract painter, dies at 42

Mar 7 Max Hymans, French WW II resistance fighter and Head of Air France, dies at 60

Thomas Beecham, English conductor (co-founded and led London Philharmonic, 1932-39; Royal Philharmonic, 1946-60), dies of heart failure at 81

Wilbur Sweatman, American ragtime and dixieland jazz clarinetist, composer, and bandleader, dies at 79

Esperanza Baur, Mexican film actress, and John Wayne's second wife, dies of a heart attack at 40

Belinda Lee, English actress (Joseph & his Brethren), dies in car crash at 25

Akiba Rubinstein, Polish chess player (openings theorist), dies at 80

Chen Geng, Chinese military leader (b. 1903)

Susanna Salter, 1st US female mayor/temperance leader, dies at 101

Edric Cundell, British composer (Serbia; The Tragedy of Deirdre) conductor, and educator (Guildhall School of Music, 1938-56), dies at 68

A.C. "Jack" Russell, English cricket batsman (10 Tests, 5 x 100s; Essex CCC), dies at 73

Mar 23 James Edward Murray, (Sen-D-Montana) (1935-61), dies

Mar 23 Valentin Vasilyevich Bondarenko, Russian cosmonaut, dies in an accident during training at 24

Jack Kane, British-Canadian arrranger, composer, and orchestra leader (Steve & Eydie; Andy Williams Show), dies at 37

Philibert Melotte, British astronomer (discovered Jupiter's 8th satellite Pasiphae), dies at 81

Seerp Anema, Dutch poet and writer (From Holland's Coasts; Modern Art and Degeneration), dies at 85

August Defresne, Dutch playwright and director (Anno Christi 969), dies at 67

Apr 2 Wallingford Riegger, American cellist, composer (New Dance; Cooper Square), and educator, dies from head injuries in a dog walking accident at 75

Simion Stoilow, Romanian mathematician (b. 1873)

Jules Bordet, Belgian bacteriologist (syphillis, Nobel 1919), dies at 90

Jesús Guridi, Spanish composer, dies at 74

Apr 7 Marian Jordan, radio comedienne (Fibber McGee & Molly), dies at 62

Apr 7 Yusef Greiss, Egyptian composer, dies at 61

Zog I [Ahmed Zogu], King of Albania (1928-39), dies at 65

Irene Warfield, American silent screen actress (Satan Sanderson), dies at about 65 [exact birthdate unconfirmed]

Francis de Bourguignon, Belgian pianist (accompanist to Nellie Melba), and contemporary classical composer, dies at 70

Nils-Eric Fougstedt, Finnish composer (Angoscia, Trittico sinfonico), dies at 50

Apr 12 Philippine "Pine" Belder [Mary de Klerk], actress, dies at 93

John A. Bennett, American convicted rapist, dies at 26

James Melton, American pop (1920-30's) and operatic tenor (Metropolitan Opera, 1942-50), dies at 57

(Joseph) Rosario Bourdon, French Canadian-American cellist, violinist, conductor, arranger and musical director (Victor Talking Machine Company, 1905-31; Symphonique de Montréal, 1935-44), dies at 76

Apr 24 Lee Moran, American actor (Circus Clown), dies of heart ailment at 72 (b. 1888)

Hans F Blunck, writer, dies

Roy Del Ruth, American filmmaker (About Face, Folies Bergere), dies at 67

(Gilbert) "Cisco" Houston, American folk singer, and guitarist, dies of stomach cancer at 42

Apr 29 (Irving Milford) "Miff" Mole, American jazz trombonist, and composer (Red Nichols and His Five Pennies - "Slippin' Around"; Sophie Tucker), dies at 63

J C White, English cricket spin bowler (15 Tests, 49 wickets; 10-76 Somerset v Worcestershire 1921), dies at 70

Maurice Merleau-Ponty, French philosopher (work on existentialism and phenomenology), dies of a heart attack at 53

Anita Stewart, American silent film actress (South of Hell Mountain), producer, and mystery novelist, dies of a heart attack at 66

Lucian Blaga, Romanian philosopher and poet (Transcendental censor), dies at 65

Gary Cooper

American 2 time Academy award-winning actor (High Noon), dies at 60

George A. Malcolm, American jurist (17th Associate Justice of the Philippine Supreme Court) and educator, dies at 79

Frans van Cauwelaert, Flemish minister and Mayor of Antwerp, dies at 81

May 17 Henri Gagnon, Canadian organist (Notre-Dame Basilica (Quebec), 1915-1961), composer (Rondel de Thibaut de Champagne), and music educator, dies at 74

Henry O'Neill, American actor ("Lady Killer"; "Nothing But Trouble"), dies at 69

Joe Howard, American vaudeville, Broadway, and television singer (Gay Nineties Revue), and songwriter ("Hello Ma Baby"), dies at 91

Josef "Pips" Priller, German fighter ace (b. 1915)

May 20 Nannie Helen Burroughs, American educator and civil rights activist (founded National Training School for Women and Girls), dies at 82

Joan Davis [Josephine Davis], American comic radio and screen actress (I Married Joan; The Rudy Vallee Show), dies of a heart attack at 48

Uuno Klami, Finnish composer (Psalmus; Kalevala Suite), dies of a heart attack while sailing at 60

Rafael Trujillo

Dominican politician, soldier and dictator of the Dominican Republic (1930-61), assassinated at 69

Walter Little, Canadian politician (b. 1877)

George S. Kaufman, American playwright (This is Show Business), dies at 72

Jun 2 Peter H "Paul" Huf, actor and director (Dutch Comedy), dies at 70

William Astbury, English physicist and chemist (pioneer in molecular biology), dies at 63

Carl Jung

Swiss Psychiatrist (founded analytic psychology), dies at 85

Robert Griffith, American theatrical producer (The Pajama Game; Damn Yankees; West Side Story), dies of a heart attack at about 55 [born c. 1907, exact date unknown]

Camille Guérin, French scientist (b. 1872)

Daniel Hoan, American politician (longest Socialist administration in the US as Mayor of Milwaukee 1916-40), dies at 80

Clinton Golden, American labor leader (founder of the United Steelworkers of America), dies at 72

Ben A. Jones, American horse trainer (US Champion trainer by earnings 1941, 43, 44, 52; Kentucky Derby x 6 including Citation, Whirlaway), dies at 78

Giulio Cabianca, Italian racing driver (b. 1923)

Jun 15 Tommy Scott, West Indian cricket spin bowler (8 Tests, 22 wickets; Jamaica), dies at 68

Marcel Junod, Swiss physician (b. 1904)

Jeff Chandler [Ira Grossel], American actor (Broken Arrow), dies as a result of medical malpractice at 42

Eddie Gaedel, American baseball pinch-hitter (shortest player in MLB history 3' 7"; St. Louis Browns), dies after mugging at 36

Betty Elder, actress (Annie Get Your Gun), dies

Jun 22 Queen Maria of Yugoslavia [Maria of Romania], Queen consort of Yugoslavia (1922-34), dies at 61

Franz de Backer, Belgian writer (White Enemy; Rubens' Daughter), dies at 70

John Alexander Douglas McCurdy, Canadian aviator, dies at 74

Jun 25 Miriam (Ma) Ferguson, US politician, 1st US elected women governor, Governor of Texas (1925-27, 1933-35), dies at 86

Kenneth F. Fearing, American poet (Afternoon of a pawnbroker), dies at 58

Harry Hooton, Australian poet, dies of cancer at 52

Jun 27 Muchtar Auezov, Kazakh writer and playwright (Enilik-Kebek), dies at 63

Jun 27 Paul Guilfoyle, American actor and director (White Heat, Cyrano de Bergerac), dies of a heart attack at 58

Lee de Forest, American inventor (Electron Tube), dies at 87

Louis-Ferdinand Céline, French writer (Die Nacht), dies at 67

Ernest Hemingway

American author (The Old Man and the Sea, Nobel Prize for Literature - 1954), dies from suicide at 61

William Franklin "Frank" Smith, American actor (Cowboy & Bandit, Scarlet Car, Frontier Days), dies of lung cancer at 83

Cuno Amiet, Swiss painter and illustrator, dies at 93

Jul 6 Enrique Larreta [E Rodriguez Maza], Argentine diplomat and writer, dies at 86

Jul 6 Scott LaFaro, American jazz bassist (Bill Evans Trio), dies in a car accident at 25

Julián Bautista, Spanish orchestral and film score composer, and conductor, dies at 60

Alan Marshal, Australian actor (Lydia, Irene, Exile Express), dies from a heart attack at 52

Erskine Butterfield, American swing and boogie-woogie jazz pianist, singer, and composer, dies at 48

Mazo de la Roche, Canadian author (b. 1879)

John E. Brownlee, Canadian politician (b. 1884)

[Louise] Sophie M E de Vries, actress (English Prof), dies at 88

Ty Cobb

American Baseball Hall of Fame outfielder (AL MVP 1911; Triple Crown 1909; 12 × AL batting champion; Detroit Tigers) and manager (Detroit Tigers 1921-26), dies of cancer at 74

Kit Guard, Danish actor (El Diablo Rides, Kid Courageous), dies of cancer at 67

Esther Dale, American actress (Curly Top; The Egg and I; Ma and Pa Kettle films), dies after surgery at 75

Theodore Chanler, American composer, dies at 59

Jesse Harper, American College Football HOF coach (Notre Dame 57–17–7 [football; 67–29 [basketball]; 88–53–1 [baseball]), dies at 77

Giovanni Battista Angioletti, Italian author (Il giorno del giudizio), dies at 64

Eva JC Beck, Dutch actress (Elckerlyc, Resurrection), dies at 63

Sidney Holland

Prime Minister of New Zealand (National: 1949-57), dies at 67

Jozef-Ernest van Roey, Belgian cardinal (opposed Nazism as Archbishop of Mechelen), dies at 87

Frank Buchman, American theologist (Moral Re-Armament), dies at 83

Franc N D Buchman, US theology (Moral Rearms), dies at 83

Aug 8 Méi Lánfāng [Lan], Chinese opera performer known as "Queen of Peking Opera" for his portrayal of female roles, dies at 66

Walter Bedell Smith, U.S. Army general (WWII) and head of CIA (1950-52), dies at 75

Antanas Škėma, Lithuanian writer actor and director (b. 1910)

Adeline De Walt Reynolds, American actress (Son of Dracula), dies at 78

Clarke Ashton Smith, American sci-fi author (Lost Worlds), dies at 68

Aug 14 Guido Alberto Fano, Italian composer and pianist, dies at 86

Aug 14 Henri-Edouard-Prosper Breuil, priest/archaeologist, dies

(Granville) "Stick" McGhee, American blues guitarist, singer and songwriter ("Drinkin' Wine. Spo-Dee-O-Dee"), dies of lung cancer at 43

Aug 15 Willie Macfarlane, Scottish golfer (US Open 1925), dies at 72

Maulvi Abdul Haq, Pakistani scholar and father of Modern Urdu, dies at 91

Carlos Salzedo, French-American piano prodigy, harpist, composer, educator (Curtis Institue; Juilliard), and new music advocate (co-founder of International Composers' Guild), dies at 76

Learned Hand, American Chief Judge of US Court of Appeals, dies at 89

Aug 18 Leonhard Frank, writer, dies at 78

(Carlos) "Charlie" Gemora, Filipino-American film make-up artist and actor who specialized in playing gorillas (Murders in the Rue Morgue; The Chimp & Swiss Miss; At the Circus; Road to Zanzibar), dies of a heart attack at 58

Percy Williams Bridgman, American physicist (Nobel 1946 - physics of high pressure), dies at 79

Aug 20 Vilhjalmur Stefansson, Canadian-American Arctic explorer and ethnologist, dies at 82

Beals Wright

American tennis player (US Nat C'ship 1905; doubles 1904-06), dies at 81

Gail Russell, American actress (The Uninvited, Moonrise, Unseen), dies from complications of alcohol abuse at 36 [1]

Tom Connolly, American Baseball HOF umpire (AL-record 8 x World Series), dies at 90

Charles Coburn, American actor (Around the World in 80 Days, Gentlemen Prefer Blondes), dies at 84

Eero Saarinen, Finnish-American architect (Dulles Airport (Virginia); Gateway Arch (St. Louis, Missouri); IBM Building (Rochester, Minnesota); MIT Chapel (Cambridge, Massachusetts)), dies while undergoing surgery for a brain tumor at 51 [1]

Sep 1 William Z. Foster, American labor organizer and US Communist Party president (1945-57), dies at 80

Greet Koeman, Dutch opera soprano, dies at 54

Robert E. Gross, American businessman (b. 1897)

Pieter Sjoerds Gerbrandy, Dutch lawyer and Prime Minister of the Netherlands (1940-45), dies at 76

Leo Carrillo, American actor (American Empire, Cisco Kid), dies at 80

Sep 10 Wolfgang von Trips, German auto racer (29 x F1 GP, 2 wins), dies in 1961 Italian Grand Prix (with 15 spectators) at 33

Carl Hermann, German physicist (crystallography), and pacifist who assisted persecuted Jews, dies at 63

A P F Chapman, cricketer (26 Tests for England), dies

Sep 16 Percy Chapman, English cricket batsman (26 Tests, captain 1926-31, 1 x 100; Kent CCC), dies after a fall at 61

Sep 16 Yme Schuitmaker, Frisian-Dutch potato merchant, actor, and playwright (Maerteblom (Snowdrop); Lysbet), dies at 84

Adnan Menderes, Turkish politician, Prime Minister of Turkey (1950-60), executed by the junta at 62

Dag Hammarskjöld

Swedish public servant, 2nd Secretary-General of the United Nations (1953-61) and posthumous Nobel Peace Prize winner (1961), dies in a plane crash in Africa at 56

Helen Kimble, fictional wife of Dr Richard Kimble (The Fugitive), murdered by a one-armed man

Sep 19 Maurice Delage, French pianist, and composer (Ragamalika; Seven Haikais), dies at 81 [date of passing may be 21 Sept]

Sep 19 Pieter Tesch, Dutch mine engineer and geologist (Pedestal of Netherlands), dies at 82

Earle Dickson, American inventor (Band-Aid), dies at 68

Sep 21 Maurice Delage, French composer, dies at 81

Marion Davies [Douras], American silent and sound film actress, producer (Little Old New York; Not So Dumb; Five and Ten), and mistress of William Randolph Hearst, dies of cancer at 64

Billy House, American actor (Imitation of Life; Bedlam; The Egg and I), dies at 71

Sep 23 Elmer Diktonius, Finnish poet, composer, and musicologist (Janne Kubrik; Stenkol), dies at 65

Sumner Welles, American diplomat (Good Neighbor Policy), dies at 68

Frank Fay, American vaudeville comedian and actor (God's Gift to Women), dies at 69

Charles Erwin Wilson, American engineer (President and CEO of General Motors) and politician (United States Secretary of Defense 1953-57), dies at 71

Sep 26 Eily Malyon, English actress (Jane Eyre, I Married a Witch), dies at 81

Sep 26 Juanita Hansen, actress (Fast Company), dies of heart ailment at 67

Hilda Doolittle, American poetess (Bid Me to Live), dies at 75
